== Greetings K/X/Ed/Ubuntu-ites! ==

=== I'm Scott (a/k/a angrykeyboarder). ===

==== Linux Experience ====
I've been a Linux user and enthusiast (on and off) since 1999. I started first with <nowiki>[[http://web.archive.org/web/20000903125324/www.linuxmandrake.com/en/|Mandrake]]</nowiki> (now known as <nowiki>[[http://www.mandriva.com/|Mandriva]]</nowiki>), then <nowiki>[[http://www.redhat.com/|RedHat]]</nowiki> and <nowiki>[[http://www.suse.com/|SUSE]]</nowiki>.  Then I went on a "hiatus" for a few years came back in 2004 starting off on <nowiki>[[http://www.fedora.redhat.com|Fedora Core 3]]</nowiki> and after that, <nowiki>[[http://www.ubuntu.com|Ubuntu]]</nowiki> and <nowiki>[[http://www.kubuntu.org|Kubuntu]]</nowiki> Hoary and have upgraded to every new version since.  I have also used <nowiki>[[http://www.debian.org/|Debian]]</nowiki> (both <nowiki>[[http://www.us.debian.org/releases/unstable/|"Unstable" -a/k/a: "sid"]]</nowiki> and <nowiki>[[http://www.us.debian.org/releases/testing/|Testing)]]</nowiki> ) and <nowiki>[[http://fedoraproject.org/|Fedora]]</nowiki> in recent times.

This all just reinforces what a great distribution (K)Ubuntu is. Although the geek in me likes to toy around, so I'll probably end up adding something later to the mix.  Regardless, I can't see myself abandoning Ubuntu/Kubuntu.  There is too much going for it. Frankly one of the best things is the unbeatable community.  They are great.

I'm not a coder or programmer, but I enjoy answering new users' questions and try to help out when I can in the <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org|forums]]</nowiki> and on the <nowiki>[[http://lists.ubuntu.com|mailing lists]]</nowiki> (and a bit less often on the IRC channels).

I have also begun dabbling in compiling Linux software from source code and building Debian (Ubuntu) packages (allthough I admit to "cheating" with <nowiki>[[http://freshmeat.net/projects/checkinstall/|"CheckInstall"]]</nowiki> ;) ).

As of this writing (28 May 2007) I'm running Feisty (with Ubuntu, Kubuntu and Xubuntu desktops installed). I spend most of my time in either KDE and GNOME.  I can't decide which of the two I like better, so I decided not to decide. ;-) I would say that I do generally lean toward KDE.  I also dual-boot with <nowiki>[[http://www.microsoft.com/windows/products/windowsvista/editions/ultimate/default.mspx|Windows Vista Ultimate]]</nowiki> (upgraded from XP in February 2007) because well...there are a few things that Windows still does better and I actually hold no ill will toward the OS.  It's pretty good actually (shh..keep that on the DL. It goes <nowiki>[[http://www.forbes.com/intelligentinfrastructure/2005/06/16/linux-bsd-unix-cz_dl_0616theo.html|against the grain]]</nowiki> of a lot of Linux people)..

I've never used an Operating System that I didn't (dis)like. :)

In any event, the geek in me likes the flexibility you get with Linux.  I spent more of my computer time in Linux than Windows.
